elements.content: Under hydrothermal conditions, two unique lead(II) frameworks {Pb1.5(NCS)2(L)0.5} n (1) and {Pb4Cl5(HL)3}n (2) (H2L = iminodiacetic acid) have been isolated. 1 represents a scarcely reported 2D lead(II) framework in which two neighboring homochiral layers parallel interpenetrate each other. Between the interpenetrating layer, interwoven double-stranded helices with the same handedness can be observed. On the other hand, 2 represents a novel 12-connected lead(II) hybrid compound based on propeller-like spiral Pb4O6 cores as nodes with two kinds of different bridges (chloride and carboxylate bridges). 2D chiral inorganic−organic hybrid layers with (3,6) topological structure can be observed, in which Pb4O6 cores (Δ or Λ geometries) are extended by μ2-Cl and μ3-Cl bridges. Anions (NCS−, Cl−) well-regulate these lead(II) frameworks via coordination bonds and secondary weak supramolecular interactions. Solid-state luminescence spectra of 1 and 2 also have been investigated.
elements.clean_text: Under hydrothermal conditions, two unique lead(II) frameworks {Pb1.5(NCS)2(L)0.5} n  (1) and {Pb4Cl5(HL)3}n (2) (H2L = iminodiacetic acid) have been isolated. 1 represents a scarcely reported 2D lead(II) framework in which two neighboring homochiral layers parallel interpenetrate each other. Between the interpenetrating layer, interwoven double-stranded helices with the same handedness can be observed. On the other hand, 2 represents a novel 12-connected lead(II) hybrid compound based on propeller-like spiral Pb4O6 cores as nodes with two kinds of different bridges (chloride and carboxylate bridges). 2D chiral inorganic-organic hybrid layers with (3,6) topological structure can be observed, in which Pb4O6 cores (Δ or Λ geometries) are extended by μ2-Cl and μ3-Cl bridges. Anions (NCS-, Cl-) well-regulate these lead(II) frameworks via coordination bonds and secondary weak supramolecular interactions. Solid-state luminescence spectra of 1 and 2 also have been investigated.

elements.content: Two lead(II) coordination compounds {Pb1.5(NCS)2(L)0.5}n (1) and {Pb4Cl5(HL)3}n (2) (H2L = iminodiacetic acid) have been isolated. 1 represents a 2D lead(II) framework in which two neighboring homochiral layers parallel interpenetrate each other. While 2 represents a 12-connected lead(II) hybrid compound based on propeller-like spiral Pb4O6 cores as nodes. Anions (NCS−, Cl−) well regulate these lead(II) frameworks via coordination bonds and secondary supramolecular interactions.
elements.clean_text: Two lead(II) coordination compounds {Pb1.5(NCS)2(L)0.5}n (1) and {Pb4Cl5(HL)3}n (2) (H2L = iminodiacetic acid) have been isolated. 1 represents a 2D lead(II) framework in which two neighboring homochiral layers parallel interpenetrate each other. While 2 represents a 12-connected lead(II) hybrid compound based on propeller-like spiral Pb4O6 cores as nodes. Anions (NCS-, Cl-) well regulate these lead(II) frameworks via coordination bonds and secondary supramolecular interactions.

elements.content: During the last two decades, metal-organic coordination polymers have aroused great interest for chemists because of their extremely versatile coordination motifs and potential applications in many areas such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), catalytic, magnetic, and so on. Especially those lead(II) frameworks also have attracted much attention based on below these points: (1) large ion radius, variable coordination numbers from 2 to 10, and diverse coordination geometries for PbII ions, indicating great potential in the construction of functional materials; (2) the intrinsic feature of PbII, the presence of a 6S2 outer electron, making PbII frameworks unique application in coordination chemistry, photophysics and photochemistry; (3) inorganic−organic hybrid lead(II) frameworks containing multidimensional Pb−X−Pb (X = O, N, Cl, S) connectivity also have aroused great interest for chemists. For example, C. N. R. Rao et al. systemically employ aromatic, cyclohexene, and cyclohexane dicarboxylic acid ligands to explore the formation of such hybrid compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

During the last two decades, metal-organic coordination polymers have aroused great interest for chemists because of their extremely versatile coordination motifs and potential applications in many areas such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), catalytic, magnetic, and so on. Especially those lead(II) frameworks also have attracted much attention based on below these points: (1) large ion radius, variable coordination numbers from 2 to 10, and diverse coordination geometries for PbII ions, indicating great potential in the construction of functional materials; (2) the intrinsic feature of PbII, the presence of a 6S2 outer electron, making PbII frameworks unique application in coordination chemistry, photophysics and photochemistry; (3) inorganic-organic hybrid lead(II) frameworks containing multidimensional Pb-X-Pb (X = O, N, Cl, S) connectivity also have aroused great interest for chemists. For example, C. N. R. Rao et al. systemically employ aromatic, cyclohexene, and cyclohexane dicarboxylic acid ligands to explore the formation of such hybrid compounds.

elements.content: Double-stranded helical structures are attractive to chemists because of their unique properties and structural relevance to DNA. However, infinite chiral double-stranded helices with only one handedness are rare and intriguing, especially for those interpenetrating compounds. Only few examples about homochiral double helices have been reported, which are of significance in the genesis of chirality in biological systems and the construction of novel chiral compounds as building blocks. On the other hand, much effort has been devoted to the construction of novel hybrid inorganic−organic compounds, in which the rigidity of the inorganic framework with the flexibility of the organic part can be combined. It is noted that the majority are based on three-, four-, and six-connected topologies with single d-and f-block metal centers as nodes. Examples of twelve-connected hybrid frameworks with heavy p-block metal clusters are extremely rare. The syntheses of those highly connected hybrid frameworks are helpful for constructing new functional coordination polymers and further understand the aggregation of metal clusters at the molecular level.
elements.clean_text: Double-stranded helical structures are attractive to chemists because of their unique properties and structural relevance to DNA. However, infinite chiral double-stranded helices with only one handedness are rare and intriguing, especially for those interpenetrating compounds. Only few examples about homochiral double helices have been reported, which are of significance in the genesis of chirality in biological systems and the construction of novel chiral compounds as building blocks. On the other hand, much effort has been devoted to the construction of novel hybrid inorganic-organic compounds, in which the rigidity of the inorganic framework with the flexibility of the organic part can be combined. It is noted that the majority are based on three-, four-, and six-connected topologies with single d-and f-block metal centers as nodes. Examples of twelve-connected hybrid frameworks with heavy p-block metal clusters are extremely rare. The syntheses of those highly connected hybrid frameworks are helpful for constructing new functional coordination polymers and further understand the aggregation of metal clusters at the molecular level.

elements.content: We have been interested in constructing novel lead(II) coordination polymers with poly carboxylate ligands. In this work, using the flexible H2L (iminodiacetic acid) ligand and corresponding lead(II) salts under hydrothermal conditions, we have isolated two novel lead(II) frameworks {Pb1.5(NCS)2(L)0.5} n (1) and {Pb4Cl5(HL)3} n (2). 1 represents a unique 2D parallel interpenetrating lead(II) framework containing interwoven homochiral double-stranded helices, whereas 2 represents an unprecedented 12-connected lead(II) hybrid framework using Pb4O6 cores as nodes. It is noted that 2D chiral inorganic−organic hybrid layers with (3,6) topological structure can be observed, in which Pb4O6 cores (Δ or Λ geometries) are extended by μ2-Cl and μ3-Cl bridges. In 1 and 2, variable lead(II) geometries, different lead(II) coordination numbers, and flexible coordination modes of carboxylate ligands reveal great potential in the construction of those novel lead(II) frameworks. Solid-state luminescence spectra of 1 and 2 have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text: We have been interested in constructing novel lead(II) coordination polymers with poly carboxylate ligands. In this work, using the flexible H2L (iminodiacetic acid) ligand and corresponding lead(II) salts under hydrothermal conditions, we have isolated two novel lead(II) frameworks {Pb1.5(NCS)2(L)0.5} n  (1) and {Pb4Cl5(HL)3} n  (2). 1 represents a unique 2D parallel interpenetrating lead(II) framework containing interwoven homochiral double-stranded helices, whereas 2 represents an unprecedented 12-connected lead(II) hybrid framework using Pb4O6 cores as nodes. It is noted that 2D chiral inorganic-organic hybrid layers with (3,6) topological structure can be observed, in which Pb4O6 cores (Δ or Λ geometries) are extended by μ2-Cl and μ3-Cl bridges. In 1 and 2, variable lead(II) geometries, different lead(II) coordination numbers, and flexible coordination modes of carboxylate ligands reveal great potential in the construction of those novel lead(II) frameworks. Solid-state luminescence spectra of 1 and 2 have also been investigated.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used without further purification. C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 400−4000 cm−1 on a Bio-Rad FTS 135 spectrometer. The photoluminescence spectrum was measured by MPF-4 fluorescence spectrophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Methods

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used without further purification. C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 400-4000 cm-1 on a Bio-Rad FTS 135 spectrometer. The photoluminescence spectrum was measured by MPF-4 fluorescence spectrophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source.

elements.content: A mixture of Pb(SCN)2 (194.1 mg, 0.6 mmol), H2L (26.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H2O (15 mL) were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined steel vessel and heated to 140 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals of 1 were washed several times by water and diethyl ether. The yield is 44% based on Pb. Anal. Calcd for C6H6N3O4Pb1.50S2: C, 12.89; H, 1.08; N, 7.52%. Found: C, 12.96; H, 1.18; N, 7.55%. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3233 m, 3134 m, 2063 s, 1635 m, 1595 m, 1469 m, 1413 m, 1375 s, 1119 m, 1002 s, 925 s, 723 m, 569 m, 521 w.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {Pb1.5(NCS)2(L)0.5} n  (1)

A mixture of Pb(SCN)2 (194.1 mg, 0.6 mmol), H2L (26.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H2O (15 mL) were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined steel vessel and heated to 140 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals of 1 were washed several times by water and diethyl ether. The yield is 44% based on Pb. Anal. Calcd for C6H6N3O4Pb1.50S2: C, 12.89; H, 1.08; N, 7.52%. Found: C, 12.96; H, 1.18; N, 7.55%. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3233 m, 3134 m, 2063 s, 1635 m, 1595 m, 1469 m, 1413 m, 1375 s, 1119 m, 1002 s, 925 s, 723 m, 569 m, 521 w.

elements.content: The compound 2 was obtained through the synthetic method similar to that of 1 except using PbCl2 (166.8 mg, 0.6 mmol) instead of Pb(SCN)2 with yields of 27% based on Pb. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals of 2 were washed several times by water and diethyl ether. Anal. Calcd for C2H3Cl0.83N0.50O2 Pb0.67: C, 10.25; H, 1.29; N, 2.98%. Found: C, 10.54; H, 1.31; N, 3.11%. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3236 m, 3170m, 3119 m, 1648 m, 1586 s, 1473 m, 1419 m, 1369 s, 1337s, 1118 s, 1017 m, 964 m, 929 s, 893 s, 687 w, 575 m, 536 w.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {Pb4Cl5(HL)3} n  (2)

The compound 2 was obtained through the synthetic method similar to that of 1 except using PbCl2 (166.8 mg, 0.6 mmol) instead of Pb(SCN)2 with yields of 27% based on Pb. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals of 2 were washed several times by water and diethyl ether. Anal. Calcd for C2H3Cl0.83N0.50O2 Pb0.67: C, 10.25; H, 1.29; N, 2.98%. Found: C, 10.54; H, 1.31; N, 3.11%. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3236 m, 3170m, 3119 m, 1648 m, 1586 s, 1473 m, 1419 m, 1369 s, 1337s, 1118 s, 1017 m, 964 m, 929 s, 893 s, 687 w, 575 m, 536 w.

elements.content: Diffraction intensities for both complexes were collected on a computer controlled Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation with radiation wavelength 0.71073 Å by using the ω-scan technique. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions and refined as riding atoms with a common fixed isotropic thermal parameter. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The large numerical corrections and relatively high residual electron density located near the Pb atoms can be compared with these previous examples. The crystallographic data are listed in Table , and selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . CCDC reference numbers 712002 (1) and 711999 (2) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this contribution. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.can.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK; Fax: (+44) 1223−336033; or deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction intensities for both complexes were collected on a computer controlled Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation with radiation wavelength 0.71073 Å by using the ω-scan technique. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions and refined as riding atoms with a common fixed isotropic thermal parameter. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The large numerical corrections and relatively high residual electron density located near the Pb atoms can be compared with these previous examples. The crystallographic data are listed in Table , and selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . CCDC reference numbers 712002 (1) and 711999 (2) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this contribution. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.can.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK; Fax: (+44) 1223-336033; or deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: For 1: #1 −x − 1/2, y, −z + 1/2; #2 −x + 1/2, y + 1, −z + 1/2. For 2: #1 −y + 1, x − y + 1, z; #2 −y + 1, x − y + 1, −z + 3/2; #3 −x + y, −x + 1, −z + 3/2; #4 −x + y + 1, −x + 1, −z + 3/2.

The H2IDA ligand is well-soluble in water at room temperature but direct solution reactions only give rise to microcrystalline precipitates, therefore the powerful hydrothermal synthetic methods were applied to obtain single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction. It is noted that the molar ratio of metal to ligand is important for the synthesis of 2. When the ratio is 3:1, 2 can be obtained. Although the molar ratio is changed to 1:1, a previously reported lead(II)-IDA compound [Pb(IDA)]n can be obtained. More lead(II) salts (PbCl2) may be helpful for chloride atoms participating into the coordination to central lead(II) ions. However, the molar ratio is not especially important for the synthesis of 1, when the molar ratio is 1:1, 1 still can be obtained, only in a smaller amount.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

The H2IDA ligand is well-soluble in water at room temperature but direct solution reactions only give rise to microcrystalline precipitates, therefore the powerful hydrothermal synthetic methods were applied to obtain single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction. It is noted that the molar ratio of metal to ligand is important for the synthesis of 2. When the ratio is 3:1, 2 can be obtained. Although the molar ratio is changed to 1:1, a previously reported lead(II)-IDA compound [Pb(IDA)]n can be obtained. More lead(II) salts (PbCl2) may be helpful for chloride atoms participating into the coordination to central lead(II) ions. However, the molar ratio is not especially important for the synthesis of 1, when the molar ratio is 1:1, 1 still can be obtained, only in a smaller amount.

elements.content: For 1, the asymmetric unit contains two independent lead(II) centers (Pb1 and Pb2), which both adopt hemidirected geometries. As shown in Figure , Pb1 is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 and O1A) and two (N)CS nitrogen atoms (N1 and N1A). Pb2 is five-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3, and O4) and one (N)CS nitrogen atom (N2). IDA2− ligands are full deprotonated and adopt η1, η1, η1, η2, μ5-coordination modes, the nitrogen atom of IDA2− is not coordinated. Pb−O and Pb−N distances vary from 2.389(0) to 2.900(5) Å, which all fall into the normal range.
elements.clean_text:
{Pb1.5(IDA)0.5(NCS)2} n  (1)

For 1, the asymmetric unit contains two independent lead(II) centers (Pb1 and Pb2), which both adopt hemidirected geometries. As shown in Figure , Pb1 is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 and O1A) and two (N)CS nitrogen atoms (N1 and N1A). Pb2 is five-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3, and O4) and one (N)CS nitrogen atom (N2). IDA2- ligands are full deprotonated and adopt η1, η1, η1, η2, μ5-coordination modes, the nitrogen atom of IDA2- is not coordinated. Pb-O and Pb-N distances vary from 2.389(0) to 2.900(5) Å, which all fall into the normal range.

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit of 1. (b) Weak Pb···S interactions in 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Asymmetric unit of 1. (b) Weak Pb⋅⋅⋅S interactions in 1.

elements.content: IDA2− ligands are linked by neighboring Pb2 atoms to form infinite right- or left-handed helical chains with a helical pitch of 13.506(3) Å, which are further linked by Pb(NCS)2 structural units forming unusual 2D homochiral layers (Figure a). For these 2D layers extraordinary large cavities with dimensionalities of 13.506(3) × 13.326(8) Å2 can be observed along the crystallographic c axis. Because of these large cavities, two neighboring layers parallel interpenetrate each other to form unique 2D homochiral interpenetrating layered structures (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: IDA2- ligands are linked by neighboring Pb2 atoms to form infinite right- or left-handed helical chains with a helical pitch of 13.506(3) Å, which are further linked by Pb(NCS)2 structural units forming unusual 2D homochiral layers (Figure a). For these 2D layers extraordinary large cavities with dimensionalities of 13.506(3) × 13.326(8) Å2 can be observed along the crystallographic c axis. Because of these large cavities, two neighboring layers parallel interpenetrate each other to form unique 2D homochiral interpenetrating layered structures (Figure b).

elements.content: Stick and spacing-filling modes of 2D homochiral interpenetrating layers containing double-stranded right-handed helices in 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  Stick and spacing-filling modes of 2D homochiral interpenetrating layers containing double-stranded right-handed helices in 1.

elements.content: Interestingly, between the 2D interpenetrating layer the same handed helical chains are further interwoven to form double-stranded helical structures. 1D homochiral microporous channels comprised of these double-stranded helices with dimensionalities of 3.400(7) × 3.047 (3) Å2 can also be observed along the crystallographic b axis. Of course the overall structure of 1 is meso-chiral because these neighboring interpenetrating 2D layers have the opposite-handed helices.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, between the 2D interpenetrating layer the same handed helical chains are further interwoven to form double-stranded helical structures. 1D homochiral microporous channels comprised of these double-stranded helices with dimensionalities of 3.400(7) × 3.047 (3) Å2 can also be observed along the crystallographic b axis. Of course the overall structure of 1 is meso-chiral because these neighboring interpenetrating 2D layers have the opposite-handed helices.

elements.content: Recently, a unique zinc(II) compound {[Zn2I4(tmdp)2] n ·[Zn2I4(tmdp)2] n } (tmdp = 4,4-trimethylenedipyridine) possessing infinite double-stranded helical chiral structure consisting of two single-stranded helices of the same handedness has been reported. Further Lah et al. also use an amino acid derivative (terephthaloyl monoalanine, L-TMA) to isolate novel Zn(II) and Cd(II) compounds containing similar chiral double-stranded helices. However, to the best of our knowledge, such interwoven double-stranded helices linked by coordination bonds further forming 2D homochiral interpenetrating frameworks are unique, especially for those lead(II) frameworks.
elements.clean_text: Recently, a unique zinc(II) compound {[Zn2I4(tmdp)2] n ⋅[Zn2I4(tmdp)2] n } (tmdp = 4,4-trimethylenedipyridine) possessing infinite double-stranded helical chiral structure consisting of two single-stranded helices of the same handedness has been reported. Further Lah et al. also use an amino acid derivative (terephthaloyl monoalanine, L-TMA) to isolate novel Zn(II) and Cd(II) compounds containing similar chiral double-stranded helices. However, to the best of our knowledge, such interwoven double-stranded helices linked by coordination bonds further forming 2D homochiral interpenetrating frameworks are unique, especially for those lead(II) frameworks.

elements.content: For the 3D supramolecular architecture of 1, weak Pb···S interactions (Pb···S distance: 3.255(1) and 3.276(1) Å) should be important for stabilizing the interpenetrating structure of 1 (Figure b). The NCS− anions well regulate the structure of 1 because of bridging Pb(NCS)2 structural units and these sulfur atoms involved in weak Pb···S interactions.
elements.clean_text: For the 3D supramolecular architecture of 1, weak Pb⋅⋅⋅S interactions (Pb⋅⋅⋅S distance: 3.255(1) and 3.276(1) Å) should be important for stabilizing the interpenetrating structure of 1 (Figure b). The NCS- anions well regulate the structure of 1 because of bridging Pb(NCS)2 structural units and these sulfur atoms involved in weak Pb⋅⋅⋅S interactions.

elements.content: When PbCl2 is used instead of Pb(NCS)2 under similar hydrothermal conditions, a 3D lead(II) complex {Pb4Cl5(HL)3}n (2) can be isolated. As shown in Figure (a), there exist two crystallographic independent lead(II) centers (Pb1 and Pb2) in 2. Pb1 is in the hemidirected geometries and six-coordinated by six carboxylate O1 atoms from six different HIDA− ligands with S3 symmetry, whereas Pb2 is in the holo-directed geometries and eight-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two different HL− ligands and four chloride atoms. Pb−O distances (2.605 and 2.91 Å) and Pb-μ2Cl (Cl2) distances (2.957 and 2.862 Å) all fall into the normal range. The Pb-μ 3 Cl (Cl1) distance is 3.055(3) Å, which is somewhat longer and can be considered as weak interactions, which also extend Pb2 into holo-directed geometries. The nitrogen atom of HIDA− is not coordinated and proton-ated, which can be correlated with acid environment of reaction solutions and is similar to the previously reported coordination polymer [Mn(HIDA)2(H2O)2] n . HIDA− ligands adopt η1, η1, η2, η2, μ6-coordination modes, which is somewhat different from that of 1.
elements.clean_text:
{Pb4Cl5(HL)3} n  (2)

When PbCl2 is used instead of Pb(NCS)2 under similar hydrothermal conditions, a 3D lead(II) complex {Pb4Cl5(HL)3}n (2) can be isolated. As shown in Figure (a), there exist two crystallographic independent lead(II) centers (Pb1 and Pb2) in 2. Pb1 is in the hemidirected geometries and six-coordinated by six carboxylate O1 atoms from six different HIDA- ligands with S3 symmetry, whereas Pb2 is in the holo-directed geometries and eight-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two different HL- ligands and four chloride atoms. Pb-O distances (2.605 and 2.91 Å) and Pb-μ2Cl (Cl2) distances (2.957 and 2.862 Å) all fall into the normal range. The Pb-μ 3 Cl (Cl1) distance is 3.055(3) Å, which is somewhat longer and can be considered as weak interactions, which also extend Pb2 into holo-directed geometries. The nitrogen atom of HIDA- is not coordinated and proton-ated, which can be correlated with acid environment of reaction solutions and is similar to the previously reported coordination polymer [Mn(HIDA)2(H2O)2] n . HIDA- ligands adopt η1, η1, η2, η2, μ6-coordination modes, which is somewhat different from that of 1.

elements.content: (a) TAsymmetric unit of 2. (b) Propeller-like Pb4O6 cores with Δ and Λ geometries. (c) Polyhedral representation of Pb4O6 cores in 2.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) TAsymmetric unit of 2. (b) Propeller-like Pb4O6 cores with Δ and Λ geometries. (c) Polyhedral representation of Pb4O6 cores in 2.

elements.content: Interestingly, Pb1 are linked by three neighboring lead(II) centers (Pb2, Pb2A, and Pb2B) through six carboxylate O1 atoms forming unique propeller-like spiral Pb4O6 cores (Figure b, Δ and Λ geometries). If these Pb4O6 cores are defined as basic nodes, an unprecedented 12-connected lead(II) framework of 314·423·516·610·73 vertex type can be determined by using the OLEX program. Two kinds of different bridges (chloride and carboxylate bridges) can be observed.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, Pb1 are linked by three neighboring lead(II) centers (Pb2, Pb2A, and Pb2B) through six carboxylate O1 atoms forming unique propeller-like spiral Pb4O6 cores (Figure b, Δ and Λ geometries). If these Pb4O6 cores are defined as basic nodes, an unprecedented 12-connected lead(II) framework of 314⋅423⋅516⋅610⋅73 vertex type can be determined by using the OLEX program. Two kinds of different bridges (chloride and carboxylate bridges) can be observed.

elements.content: Further analysis reveals that these Pb4O6 cores with Δ or Λ geometries are extended by μ2-Cl and μ3-Cl bridging ligands forming chiral inorganic−organic hybrid layers (structures a and b in Figure ). These 2D chiral hybrid layers can be considered to have novel 6-coordinated (3,6) topology structures. Such chiral hybrid layers also can be observed in those metal phosphate materials, which are particularly desirable because of their promising applications in enantioselective catalysis and separation. For example, a new open-framework aluminophosphate containing propeller-like chiral motifs has been synthesized solvothermally using 2-aminopyridine as the structure-directing agent.
elements.clean_text: Further analysis reveals that these Pb4O6 cores with Δ or Λ geometries are extended by μ2-Cl and μ3-Cl bridging ligands forming chiral inorganic-organic hybrid layers (structures a and b in Figure ). These 2D chiral hybrid layers can be considered to have novel 6-coordinated (3,6) topology structures. Such chiral hybrid layers also can be observed in those metal phosphate materials, which are particularly desirable because of their promising applications in enantioselective catalysis and separation. For example, a new open-framework aluminophosphate containing propeller-like chiral motifs has been synthesized solvothermally using 2-aminopyridine as the structure-directing agent.

elements.content: On the other hand, these Pb4O6 cores are linked through organic HIDA− bridging ligands forming another six-connected honeycomb framework with 4966 topology (Figure ). Numerous coordination frameworks with 6-connected topology have been reported, only few examples deal with 3D 4966 topology. For example, G. Raptis et al. reported a unique porous silver framework with uninodal 4966 network.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, these Pb4O6 cores are linked through organic HIDA- bridging ligands forming another six-connected honeycomb framework with 4966 topology (Figure ). Numerous coordination frameworks with 6-connected topology have been reported, only few examples deal with 3D 4966 topology. For example, G. Raptis et al. reported a unique porous silver framework with uninodal 4966 network.

elements.content: (a) Pb4O6 cores are extended by HIDA− ligands forming the six-connected framework in 2. (b) 6-connected 4966 topological structure (Pb4O6 cores are defined as nodes).
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Pb4O6 cores are extended by HIDA- ligands forming the six-connected framework in 2. (b) 6-connected 4966 topological structure (Pb4O6 cores are defined as nodes).

elements.content: As shown in Figure , μ2 -Cl and μ3 -Cl anions play the important roles in regulating the framework structure of 2. Although μ3 -Cl bridges are scarcely reported in these lead(II) frameworks, in general, μ3 -Cl bridges can be observed in the cubane framework. Recently, a new class of heptacopper(II) clusters [Cu7(μ3 -OH)6(μ3 -Cl)2(D-pends)3] (D-pends = d-penicill aminedisulfides) with an acentrosymmetric corner-sharing double-cubane Cu4(μ 3 -Cl)4 framework can be isolated.
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figure , μ2 -Cl and μ3 -Cl anions play the important roles in regulating the framework structure of 2. Although μ3 -Cl bridges are scarcely reported in these lead(II) frameworks, in general, μ3 -Cl bridges can be observed in the cubane framework. Recently, a new class of heptacopper(II) clusters [Cu7(μ3 -OH)6(μ3 -Cl)2(D-pends)3] (D-pends = d-penicill aminedisulfides) with an acentrosymmetric corner-sharing double-cubane Cu4(μ 3  -Cl)4 framework can be isolated.

elements.content: Overall 12-connected framework using Pb4O6 cores as nodes (green lines represent μ2-Cl and μ3-Cl bridges, whereas gray lines represent carboxylate bridges).
elements.clean_text: 6  Overall 12-connected framework using Pb4O6 cores as nodes (green lines represent μ2-Cl and μ3-Cl bridges, whereas gray lines represent carboxylate bridges).

elements.content: Photoluminescence properties of s2-metal complexes are not well studied as compared with those of d10 metal complexes. The solid-state fluorescence emission properties of 1−2 were investigated at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibits an intense fluorescent emission maximum at λem = 619 nm (λex = 465 nm), whereas 2 displays maxima emissions at 607 nm (λex = 451 nm), respectively (not shown). The low-energy fluorescence emissions of 1−2 are commonly observed for other s2-metal complexes, which can be assigned to a metal-centered transition involving the s and p metal orbital as proposed by Vogler. The different emission bands between 1 and 2 may be attributed to the coordination diversity of the lead(II) centers and the rigidity difference of these lead(II) frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Properties of 1 and 2 

Photoluminescence properties of s2-metal complexes are not well studied as compared with those of d10 metal complexes. The solid-state fluorescence emission properties of 1-2 were investigated at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibits an intense fluorescent emission maximum at λem = 619 nm (λex = 465 nm), whereas 2 displays maxima emissions at 607 nm (λex = 451 nm), respectively (not shown). The low-energy fluorescence emissions of 1-2 are commonly observed for other s2-metal complexes, which can be assigned to a metal-centered transition involving the s and p metal orbital as proposed by Vogler. The different emission bands between 1 and 2 may be attributed to the coordination diversity of the lead(II) centers and the rigidity difference of these lead(II) frameworks.

elements.content: In summary, two unique lead(II) frameworks {Pb1.5(IDA)0.5(NCS)2} n (1) and {Pb4Cl5(HL)3} n (2) (H2IDA = iminodiacetic acid) have been isolated and structurally characterized under hydrothermal conditions. 1 represents a unique 2D parallel interpenetrating lead(II) framework containing interwoven homochiral double-stranded helices, whereas 2 represents an unprecedented 12-connected lead(II) hybrid framework using Pb4O6 cores as nodes. IDA2− ligands adopt two different coordination modes in 1 and 2. The central lead(II) ions are in the hemidirected geometries in 1, whereas they are in the hemi- and holo-directed geometries in 2. The variable lead(II) geometries, variable lead(II) coordination numbers, and flexible coordination modes of carboxylate ligands reveal great potential in the construction of novel lead(II) frameworks. 1 and 2 also exhibit strong emissions and may be potential materials for emitting diode devices.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, two unique lead(II) frameworks {Pb1.5(IDA)0.5(NCS)2} n  (1) and {Pb4Cl5(HL)3} n  (2) (H2IDA = iminodiacetic acid) have been isolated and structurally characterized under hydrothermal conditions. 1 represents a unique 2D parallel interpenetrating lead(II) framework containing interwoven homochiral double-stranded helices, whereas 2 represents an unprecedented 12-connected lead(II) hybrid framework using Pb4O6 cores as nodes. IDA2- ligands adopt two different coordination modes in 1 and 2. The central lead(II) ions are in the hemidirected geometries in 1, whereas they are in the hemi- and holo-directed geometries in 2. The variable lead(II) geometries, variable lead(II) coordination numbers, and flexible coordination modes of carboxylate ligands reveal great potential in the construction of novel lead(II) frameworks. 1 and 2 also exhibit strong emissions and may be potential materials for emitting diode devices.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Pb(SCN)2 (194.1 mg, 0.6 mmol), H2L (26.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H2O (15 mL) were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined steel vessel and heated to 140 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals of 1 were washed several times by water and diethyl ether. The yield is 44% based on Pb. Anal. Calcd for C6H6N3O4Pb1.50S2: C, 12.89; H, 1.08; N, 7.52%. Found: C, 12.96; H, 1.18; N, 7.55%. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3233 m, 3134 m, 2063 s, 1635 m, 1595 m, 1469 m, 1413 m, 1375 s, 1119 m, 1002 s, 925 s, 723 m, 569 m, 521 w.

Synthesis of {Pb<sub>4</sub>Cl<sub>5</sub>(HL)<sub>3</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

The compound 2 was obtained through the synthetic method similar to that of 1 except using PbCl2 (166.8 mg, 0.6 mmol) instead of Pb(SCN)2 with yields of 27% based on Pb. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals of 2 were washed several times by water and diethyl ether. Anal. Calcd for C2H3Cl0.83N0.50O2 Pb0.67: C, 10.25; H, 1.29; N, 2.98%. Found: C, 10.54; H, 1.31; N, 3.11%. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3236 m, 3170m, 3119 m, 1648 m, 1586 s, 1473 m, 1419 m, 1369 s, 1337s, 1118 s, 1017 m, 964 m, 929 s, 893 s, 687 w, 575 m, 536 w.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {Pb1.5(NCS)2(L)0.5} n  (1)

A mixture of Pb(SCN)2 (194.1 mg, 0.6 mmol), H2L (26.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H2O (15 mL) were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined steel vessel and heated to 140 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals of 1 were washed several times by water and diethyl ether. The yield is 44% based on Pb. Anal. Calcd for C6H6N3O4Pb1.50S2: C, 12.89; H, 1.08; N, 7.52%. Found: C, 12.96; H, 1.18; N, 7.55%. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3233 m, 3134 m, 2063 s, 1635 m, 1595 m, 1469 m, 1413 m, 1375 s, 1119 m, 1002 s, 925 s, 723 m, 569 m, 521 w.

Synthesis of {Pb4Cl5(HL)3} n  (2)

The compound 2 was obtained through the synthetic method similar to that of 1 except using PbCl2 (166.8 mg, 0.6 mmol) instead of Pb(SCN)2 with yields of 27% based on Pb. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals of 2 were washed several times by water and diethyl ether. Anal. Calcd for C2H3Cl0.83N0.50O2 Pb0.67: C, 10.25; H, 1.29; N, 2.98%. Found: C, 10.54; H, 1.31; N, 3.11%. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3236 m, 3170m, 3119 m, 1648 m, 1586 s, 1473 m, 1419 m, 1369 s, 1337s, 1118 s, 1017 m, 964 m, 929 s, 893 s, 687 w, 575 m, 536 w.

cln_elements.content:
IDA2− ligands are linked by neighboring Pb2 atoms to form infinite right- or left-handed helical chains with a helical pitch of 13.506(3) Å, which are further linked by Pb(NCS)2 structural units forming unusual 2D homochiral layers (Figure a). For these 2D layers extraordinary large cavities with dimensionalities of 13.506(3) × 13.326(8) Å2 can be observed along the crystallographic c axis. Because of these large cavities, two neighboring layers parallel interpenetrate each other to form unique 2D homochiral interpenetrating layered structures (Figure b).

Interestingly, between the 2D interpenetrating layer the same handed helical chains are further interwoven to form double-stranded helical structures. 1D homochiral microporous channels comprised of these double-stranded helices with dimensionalities of 3.400(7) × 3.047 (3) Å2 can also be observed along the crystallographic b axis. Of course the overall structure of 1 is meso-chiral because these neighboring interpenetrating 2D layers have the opposite-handed helices.

Fluorescence Properties of <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold>

Photoluminescence properties of s2-metal complexes are not well studied as compared with those of d10 metal complexes. The solid-state fluorescence emission properties of 1−2 were investigated at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibits an intense fluorescent emission maximum at λem = 619 nm (λex = 465 nm), whereas 2 displays maxima emissions at 607 nm (λex = 451 nm), respectively (not shown). The low-energy fluorescence emissions of 1−2 are commonly observed for other s2-metal complexes, which can be assigned to a metal-centered transition involving the s and p metal orbital as proposed by Vogler. The different emission bands between 1 and 2 may be attributed to the coordination diversity of the lead(II) centers and the rigidity difference of these lead(II) frameworks.
cln_elements.clean_text:
IDA2- ligands are linked by neighboring Pb2 atoms to form infinite right- or left-handed helical chains with a helical pitch of 13.506(3) Å, which are further linked by Pb(NCS)2 structural units forming unusual 2D homochiral layers (Figure a). For these 2D layers extraordinary large cavities with dimensionalities of 13.506(3) × 13.326(8) Å2 can be observed along the crystallographic c axis. Because of these large cavities, two neighboring layers parallel interpenetrate each other to form unique 2D homochiral interpenetrating layered structures (Figure b).

Interestingly, between the 2D interpenetrating layer the same handed helical chains are further interwoven to form double-stranded helical structures. 1D homochiral microporous channels comprised of these double-stranded helices with dimensionalities of 3.400(7) × 3.047 (3) Å2 can also be observed along the crystallographic b axis. Of course the overall structure of 1 is meso-chiral because these neighboring interpenetrating 2D layers have the opposite-handed helices.

Fluorescence Properties of 1 and 2 

Photoluminescence properties of s2-metal complexes are not well studied as compared with those of d10 metal complexes. The solid-state fluorescence emission properties of 1-2 were investigated at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibits an intense fluorescent emission maximum at λem = 619 nm (λex = 465 nm), whereas 2 displays maxima emissions at 607 nm (λex = 451 nm), respectively (not shown). The low-energy fluorescence emissions of 1-2 are commonly observed for other s2-metal complexes, which can be assigned to a metal-centered transition involving the s and p metal orbital as proposed by Vogler. The different emission bands between 1 and 2 may be attributed to the coordination diversity of the lead(II) centers and the rigidity difference of these lead(II) frameworks.

metadata.title: Hydrothermal Syntheses and Characterization of Two Novel Lead(II)-IDA Coordination Polymers: From 2D Homochiral Parallel Interpenetration to 12-Connected Lead(II) Hybrid Framework Based on Propeller-Like Spiral Pb4O6 Cores (H2IDA = iminodiacetic acid)
